It's actually a good question. We're told that there are trillions of stars in the sky, yet at night we only see a handful. 
The reason is that the light from all the other stars in the universe hasn't had time to reach us yet. For instance, a star could be dying right now, but it could take millions of years for us to see it being born, and millions more for us to see it dying.
That, and (obviously) the brightest object in the sky, the sun, is on the other side of the Earth.

When you exercise vigorously you sweat a lot and lose water and electrolytes, which results in dehydration. This loss of water volume in your blood causes your blood pressure to drop and less oxygen gets to your brain. As a result, after extreme exercise, you feel weak, dizzy, from lack of oxygen, and the dizziness can cause nausea. If you are severely dehydrated you can stop sweating and your body temp will rise, also causing nausea and vomiting. It's happened to me while hiking, scary stuff.

The gravitational force of a planet (or item) is in proportion to it's mass, which means heavier planet = greater gravity. This explains why astronauts "bounce" on the surface of the moon :)

Same thing goes with laughter, which is why most comedy-shows use a laughtrack. By hearing (or seeing) other people laugh, we are more likely to laugh as well. This also explains why deaf people laugh at funny stuff too, even if they can't hear themselves or others, it's a social behaviour :)

The hearing and the balancing parts of the ear are two different components, which means that generally deaf people have just as good balance as people without hearing-impairments. You don't need the outer parts (ie, the visible parts) of the ear for balance, so as long as the vestibular system of the inner ears are intact, you're fine! :)
